page.title: Akademikerne – The Danish Confederation of Professional Associations

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= Akademikerne (AC) |country= [[Denmark]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[ETUC]], [[TUAC]], [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions|NFS]] |members= 313,000 (2014) |full_name= Akademikerne – The Danish Confederation of Professional Associations |native_name= Akademikerne (AC) |founded= 1972 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Copenhagen]], Denmark |people= [[President]] [[Finn R. Larsen]]
([[Physician|Medical Doctor]], [[Chief Physician]], [[Anesthesiologist]], [[Master of Public Administration|MPA]]) |website= [http://www.ac.dk/ ac.dk] |footnotes= }} '''Akademikerne – The Danish Confederation of Professional Associations''' [[Danish language|Danish]]: ''Akademikerne'' was founded in 1972 and is an [[umbrella organisation]] (one of the three [[national trade union center]]s) for 25 [[Denmark|Danish]] [[trade union]]s. Akademikerne has a membership of 313,000 and cooperates with the two other Danish [[National trade union center|trade union centers]], i.e. the [[FTF – Confederation of Professionals in Denmark]] and the [[LO, The Danish Confederation of Trade Unions]]. Members of the 25 trade unions of Akademikerne are typically [[employee]]s with a [[higher education]], i.e. a [[master's degree]] or a [[postgraduate education]]. Members of Akademikerne are e.g. [[lawyer]]s, [[librarian]]s, [[psychologist]]s, [[dentist]]s, [[veterinarian]]s, [[pharmacist]]s, [[high school]] [[teacher]]s, [[medical doctor]]s etc. Akademikerne is affiliated with the [[International Trade Union Confederation|International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC)]], the [[European Trade Union Confederation|European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC)]], the [[Trade Union Advisory Committee to the OECD|Trade Union Advisory Committee to the OECD (TUAC)]] and the [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions|Council of Nordic Trade Unions (NFS)]]. ==Members== * [[Danish Union of Architects]] * [[sh Union of Librarians]] * [[Dansk Kiroprator Forening]] * [[Dansk Magisterforening]] * [[Dansk Mejeriingeniør Forening]] * Dansk Musikpædagogisk Forening * Dansk Organist og Kantor Samfund * Dansk Psykolog Forening * De Offentlige Tandlæger * De Offentlige Tandlæger * Den Danske Dyrlægeforening * Den danske Præsteforening * Forbundet Kommunikation og Sprog * Foreningen af Akademisk Uddannede DJ-medlemmer * Foreningen af Kliniske Diætister * Foreningen af Skibsinspektører i Søfartsstyrelsen * Foreningen af Speciallæger * Forsvarsgruppen i AC * Gymnasieskolernes Lærerforening * Handelsskolernes Lærerforening, Adjunkt/lektorgruppen * [[Danish Society of Engineers]] * JA * [[Danish Medical Association]] * Pharmadanmark * Praktiserende Lægers Organisation * Tandlægeforeningen * Yngre Læger ==See also== {{Portal|Organised labour}} *[[FTF – Confederation of Professionals in Denmark]] *[[LO, The Danish Confederation of Trade Unions]] ==External links== *[http://www.ac.dk/ Akademikernes Official Website (in Danish)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Akademikerne - {{MedalSilver|[[2015 European Athletics U23 Championships|2015 Tallinn]]|[[2015 European Athletics U23 Championships – Women's 20 kilometres walk|20 km walk]]}} }} '''Anežka Drahotová''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈanɛʃka ˈdraɦotovaː}}; born 22 July 1995, [[Rumburk]]) is a Czech [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] competitor in [[racewalking]], [[middle-distance running]], and [[Steeplechase (athletics)|steeplechase]], as well an international level [[cycling|cyclist]]. She is the [[Czech records in athletics|Czech record]] holder for the [[20 kilometres walk]] (1:29:05 – equal with [[Barbora Dibelková]]) and the [[10 kilometres race walk|10 km track walk]] (44:15.87 minutes). In her first major international competitions, she placed seventh in the junior category at the [[2011 European Race Walking Cup]] and sixth in the 5000 m walk at the [[2011 World Youth Championships in Athletics]]. The following year she ranked sixth in the 10 km walk at the [[2012 World Junior Championships in Athletics]], where she also placed 25th overall in the [[1500 metres]]. The [[2013 European Race Walking Cup]] saw her take the bronze medal in the 10 km walk event. She won the 20 km walk gold medal in the [[2013 European Athletics Junior Championships]], while her twin sister [[Eliška Drahotová]] took the bronze. In an unusual event combination, she also entered the [[3000 metres steeplechase]] and placed ninth.{{cite web|title=Opening honours to the Drahotová twins |url=http://www.european-athletics.org/rieti-2013-news/12097-opening-honours-to-the-drahotova-twins.html |work=22nd European Athletics Junior Championships, Rieti/ITA, 18–21 July 2013 |publisher=European Athletics |accessdate=13 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130720010122/http://www.european-athletics.org/rieti-2013-news/12097-opening-honours-to-the-drahotova-twins.html |archivedate=20 July 2013 |df= }} She placed outside the medals, taking seventh place, in the [[2013 World Championships in Athletics]] held in [[Moscow]] in the [[2013 World Championships in Athletics – Women's 20 kilometres walk|20 km walk]] despite leading the race for some kilometers and notching a personal best time of 1:29:05.{{cite web|title=20 Kilometres Race Walk Result - 14th IAAF World Championship|url=http://www.iaaf.org/competitions/iaaf-world-championships/14th-iaaf-world-championships-4873/results/women/20-kilometres-race-walk/final|publisher=IAAF|accessdate=13 August 2013|date=13 August 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/athletes/biographies/country=cze/athcode=255370/index.html |title=Anežka Drahotova|work=IAAF Profile|publisher=[[IAAF]]|accessdate=13 August 2013}} She proved adept at running by finishing as the first Czech athlete at the [[Prague Grand Prix]] [[10K run]] that year. Her global debut in cycling also came that year at the [[2013 UCI Road World Championships]]. There she placed 19th in the [[2013 UCI Road World Championships – Women's junior road race|junior road race]].Trojakova, Zuzana (2013-11-19). [http://www.iaaf.org/news/feature/walking-running-cycling-anezka-drahotova-2014 Walking, running, cycling – Anezka Drahotova excels at them all]. IAAF. Retrieved on 2013-11-19. In 2013 her world ranking in the women's 20 km walk was 21st place overall.{{cite web|title=Profile of Anežka DRAHOTOVÁ|url=http://www.all-athletics.com/node/332690|work=All-Athletics.com|publisher=Elite Ltd.|accessdate=13 August 2013}} ==Competition record in athletics== {| {{AchievementTable|Event=yes}} |- {{multiple issues| {{notability|Music|date=September 2009}} {{refimprove|date=September 2009}} }} {{Infobox musical artist | name = B'Avarija | image = B'Avarija en 2003.jpg | image_size = | landscape = yes | alt = | caption = B'Avarija in August 2003 ([[Šventoji, Lithuania|Šventoji]]) | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Lithuania]], [[Klaipėda]] | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | years_active = {{start date|1996}}–present | label = | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.bavarija.lt/}} (Defunct) | current_members = [[Juozas Liesis]]
[[Deivydas Zvonkus]]
[[Vilius Tarasovas]] | past_members = [[Ramūnas Stankevičius]]
[[Robertas Rezgevičius]]
[[Darius Beinortas]]
[[Jonas Jonušas]] }} '''B'Avarija''' is a musical band in [[Lithuania]], [[Klaipėda]], which was formed in 1996. They won a lot of awards for best songs. They have made several attempts to win the Lithuanian national finals in order to represent the country in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] but no attempt was successful. In 2002, they won the finals with their song "We All", however this win had to be disqualified, just over a month later as the song had been released the previous year in [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]], under the title "Mes čia!" (We Are Here). Under the rules, a song may not be released before 1 January of the year of the relevant contest. Officials argued that the lyrics were different (as it was in a different language) and therefore a different song, however the [[EBU]] rules that the song was not different enough and therefore could not be used in the main [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002]]. It is thought that the Lithuanian broadcasters had not fully understood the rules as a number of the songs competing in the final had also been released earlier. [[Aivaras Stepukonis|Aivaras]], who was second in the national finals, went to the contest for [[Lithuania]] instead. == Members == * [[Juozas Liesis]] * [[Deivydas Zvonkus]] * [[Ramūnas Stankevičius]] (until 1996) * [[Robertas Rezgevičius]] (until 1996) * [[Vilius Tarasovas]] (since 1996) * [[Darius Beinortas]](from 1997 to 2000) * [[Jonas Jonušas]] (from 1997 to 2000) ==Attempts at Eurovision== #1999 - Nešk mane (Take Me) - Came fourth in the national final #1999 - Pamiršk (Forget It) - Placing unknown #2001 - Duok man (Give Me) - Came third in the national final #2002 - We All - Came first in national final but disqualified afterwards #2004 - I Know - Came equal fourth place in the national final with [[Amberlife]]'s song "In Your Eyes" #2005 - Oceans of Love - Came tenth in the national final #2006 - If My Dream Came True - Came fifteenth in the national final *In 1999, the band entered two songs (this is not a typing error) *"I know" is also known as "Labai, Labai" in Lithuanian == Discography == * „Naktį ir dieną minutę, kiekvieną“ (1996) * „Duok man jėgų“ (1997) * „Arti“ (1999) * „Mylėk mane“ (2000) * „Iš visos širdies“ (2001) * „Angelay“ (2003) * „Labai“ (2003) * „[[Spalvotas]]“ (2004) * „Gazas“ (2005) == External links == * [http://www.lyred.com/lyrics/B'avarija/ Lyrics] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8ci8avrtOXs B'Avarija on Youtube] * [http://www.last.fm/music/B%2527avarija B'Avarija on last.fm] * [https://www.pakartot.lt/project/bavarija Listen to B'Avarija tracks] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Lithuanian pop music groups]] {{Lithuania-stub}} {{europe-band-stub}}

{{ref improve|date=February 2013}} '''''Bacalhau com todos''''' (literally meaning "codfish with everything" in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]<ref>{{cite book|author1=Madison Books|author2=Andrews McMeel Publishing|title=1,001 Foods to Die For|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptZgNoobsyUC|date=1 November 2007|publisher=Andrews McMeel Publishing|isbn=978-0-7407-7043-2|page=267}}</ref>) is a common [[bacalhau]] recipe in [[Portuguese cuisine]]. It consists of boiled codfish, boiled vegetables (such as potato, carrots and cabbage), and [[hard-boiled egg]]. It is served seasoned with [[olive oil]] infused with [[garlic]] and, depending on taste, also [[white wine]] [[vinegar]].
==See also== {{portal|Food}} * [[List of Portuguese dishes]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Portuguese cuisine]] [[Category:Fish dishes]] [[Category:Christmas food]]

{{unreferenced|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Buletin Siang | camera = [[Multicamera setup]] | creator = [[Desi Anwar]] | starring = [[Dana Iswara]], [[Atika Suri]] | country = {{flagcountry|Indonesia}} | language = [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] | location = [[Jakarta]] | runtime = 30 minutes | network = [[RCTI]] 1993-2009
[[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]] 1993-1996 | picture_format = [[576i]] ([[SDTV]]) | audio_format = [[Stereo]] | first_run = 24 August 1993 | first_aired = 24 August 1993 | last_aired = 9 February 2009 | followed_by = Seputar Indonesia Siang | website = http://www.rcti.tv/news/index.php }} '''''Buletin Siang''''' (lit. ''Noon Bulletin'') is the first noon [[newscast]] ever produced by an [[Indonesia]]n private [[television]] station it was launched on 24 August 1993 on privately owned [[RCTI]] private [[television station]] in [[Indonesia]], Buletin Siang was also carried by RCTI's then sister station [[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]]. On 9 February 2009, Seputar Indonesia was revived and is the only news program on [[RCTI]], now called '''Satu Seputar Indonesia'''. The morning news program, [[Nuansa Pagi]] was renamed '''Seputar Indonesia Pagi'''. The afternoon news program, Buletin Siang renamed '''Seputar Indonesia Siang'''. The late night news program, [[Buletin Malam]] was renamed '''Seputar Indonesia Malam'''. The main evening edition retained the '''Seputar Indonesia''' name due to the historical context. == Logos== Since Buletin Siang once on the air,Buletin siang logos is used with Purple Square and Word ''BULETIN SIANG'' with Orange circle and narrow Triangle by the logos is used on 24 August 1993 until 31 October 1999. On 1 November 1999, the Buletin Siang Logos is not Used logos with purple square and now the logos was used with blue circle and white circle inside and was used from 24 August 1993 logo now with blue narrow triangle by the logos was used until 7 August 2003. On 8 August 2003, the Buletin Siang logos was used from 1999 logos with [[3D computer graphics|3D]] Graphics by the logos was used until 23 August 2006. On 24 August 2006, the logos becomes as [[Seputar Indonesia]] Logos was introduced on 24 August 2006 until 9 February 2009. ==Chronology Programs== ===Rubrication=== *''''''Buletin Wanita''''' (1993-2001) *''''''Wajah''''' (1993-2001) ==Anchors & former anchors== * [[Gustav Aulia]] * Dentamira Kusuma * Chrysanti Suwarso * Fauziah Dasuki * Ratna Komala *[[Atika Suri]] *[[Desi Anwar]] * Dana Iswara * Zsa Zsa Yusharyahya * [[Aiman Witjaksono]] ==See also== *[[Seputar Indonesia]] *[[Nuansa Pagi]] *[[Buletin Malam]] [[Category:Indonesian television news programmes]] [[Category:1993 Indonesian television series debuts]] [[Category:1990s Indonesian television series]] [[Category:2000s Indonesian television series]] [[Category:2009 Indonesian television series endings]] {{indonesia-stub}} {{Indonesia-tv-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox broadcasting network | name = Dream Satellite TV | logo = [[File:Dream Satellite TV logo.png]] | type = [[Direct-broadcast satellite]] [[satellite television|television]] | country = [[Philippines]] | available = Defunct | founder = {{Start date and age|1997|04}} | slogan = "Reaching You, Touching You" | headquarters = DREAM Broadcast Center, [[Clark Special Economic Zone]], [[Pampanga]], Philippines | owner = Philippine Multi-Media System, Inc. | key_people = Antonio Tonyboy Conjuangco <small>(Chairman)</small> | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2001|04|22}} | dissolved = {{Start date and age|2017|12|31}} | Picture format = [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB]], [[NTSC]] | website = {{URL|www.dream.com.ph}} }} '''Dream Satellite TV''' was the first all-digital [[Direct-To-Home]] (DTH) [[television]] broadcasting service via [[satellite]] in the [[Philippines]]. Broadcasting from the Dream Broadcast Center located at the [[Clark Special Economic Zone]] in [[Pampanga]]. Content is received from program providers, compressed and broadcast via [[2006 in spaceflight#August|Koreasat 5]] (Mugunghwa 5) in [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB-S]] and [[NTSC]] color format exclusively to its subscribers using the Integrated Receiver-Decoder and the Conax/Nagravision 3 Encryption System.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tianjin-satellitetv.com/dreamtvmigrating.html | title=Dream Satellite TV Migrated into KoreaSat 5 at 113.0 °E | publisher=''[[Tianjin Television|Tianjin Satellite TV Service Center]]'' | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111100009/http://www.tianjin-satellitetv.com/dreamtvmigrating.html | archivedate=November 11, 2013 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mb.com.ph/node/236266 | title=Dream TV Taps South Korea's Mugunghwa 5 Satellite | publisher=''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905105114/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/236266 | archivedate=September 5, 2012 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/dream.html | title=Dream Satellite TV on Koreasat 5 at 113.0°E | publisher=''Lyngemark Satellite'' | date=November 9, 2013 | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111093608/http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/dream.html | archivedate=November 11, 2013 | df= }}</ref>
To receive Dream's broadcasting signals, subscribers must acquire a {{convert|60|cm}} in diameter [[satellite dish]] [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]], an Integrated Receiver-Decoder (IRD) and a Dream Conditional Access Card ([[Smart Card]]). To provide security and protection, the satellite signals of Dream shall be encrypted using a Conditional Access System. Thus, exclusive use of Dream programs and services will only be available to Dream subscribes.
==History== ===1996-2001: Incorporation and launch=== In April 1996, Dream was incorporated to the Philippine Multi-Media System, Inc. (PMSI). On February 6, 1998, the [[Philippine Congress]] passed into law Republic Act No. 8630 which granted PMSI a franchise to construct, install, maintain and operate for commercial purposes and in the public interest, television and radio broadcasting in the Philippines. The franchise term is 25 years.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.congress.gov.ph/download/ra_10/RA08630.pdf | title=Republic Act No. 8630: An Act granting the Philippine Multi-Media System, Inc., a franchise to construct, install, establish, operate and maintain radio And television stations in the Philippines | publisher=''[[Congress of the Philippines]]'' | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111094243/http://www.congress.gov.ph/download/ra_10/RA08630.pdf | archivedate=November 11, 2013 | df= }}</ref> On February 1, 2000, The National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) granted a provisional authority to engage in Direct-To-Home (DTH) satellite services. On February 7, 2001, the PMSI inaugurates its Dream Broadcasting Center at Clark Development Center, and on April 22, 2001, the commercial launch of Dream Broadcasting System, the first DTH system in the Philippines, took place.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dream.com.ph/aboutus/about_history.asp?npage=66 | title=Historical Highlights | publisher=''Dream Satellite TV'' | accessdate=November 11, 2013}}</ref>
In 2003, Dream Broadcasting System was renamed as "'''Dream Satellite TV'''".
===2006-2011: Koreasat 5 secondary broadcast and Agila II closedown=== On 2006, Dream began to use Koreasat 5 as an additional additional main broadcast to the
Starting 2010 until 2011, Dream closed all of the transponders of Agila II (ABS-5/ABS-3) for its main broadcast, due to the fact that it was only 2 years left in the orbit. When all of the Dream Satellite channels were transferred to Koreasat 5, Dream announced customers to migrate their receivers (which uses Nagravision 3/Conax CAS7) to Koreasat 5 as the replacement for ABS-5/ABS-3 satellite.
In 2011, Antonio "Tonyboy" O. Cojuangco, Jr., owner of PMSI, has plans to sell the company.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://rp1.abs-cbnnews.com/business/07/06/11/cojuangco-talks-sell-dream-tv | title=Cojuangco in talks to sell Dream TV | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' | work=[[BusinessMirror]] | date=July 6, 2011 | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114191551/http://rp1.abs-cbnnews.com/business/07/06/11/cojuangco-talks-sell-dream-tv | archive-date=2013-11-14 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> In August 2013, it was revealed that [[SkyCable]] was in the advanced stages of negotiations of acquisition of PMSI.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://businessmirror.com.ph/index.php/en/business/companies/17788-skycable-on-the-lookout-for-possible-acquisitions | title=SkyCable on the lookout for possible acquisitions | publisher=''[[BusinessMirror]]'' | date=August 11, 2013 | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | author=Lenie Lectura | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111100208/http://businessmirror.com.ph/index.php/en/business/companies/17788-skycable-on-the-lookout-for-possible-acquisitions | archivedate=November 11, 2013 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://nextvasia.com/1-cable-dth/philippines-based-telecom-company-sky-cable-looks-to-acquire-another-cable-operator/ | title=Philippines-based telecom company Sky Cable looks to acquire another DTH player | publisher=''NexTV Asia'' | date=August 12, 2013 | accessdate=November 11, 2013 | author=Aishwariya S | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111093502/http://nextvasia.com/1-cable-dth/philippines-based-telecom-company-sky-cable-looks-to-acquire-another-cable-operator/ | archive-date=2013-11-11 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref>
===2017: Koreasat 7 third broadcast===
In 2017 Dream stated that it is planning to sign a multi-year, multi-transponder capacity agreement with [[South Korea|Korea]]-based [[KT Corporation]] to broadcast DTH television channels via Koreasat 7 satellite at 116.0 degrees East & upgrade to [[DVB-S2]]. Koreasat 7 is expected to be operational by middle of 2017 to compete among 3 dth operators in the Philippines.
===The end of Dream Satellite TV===
Effective December 31, 2017, Dream Satellite TV will cease their operations after 16 years due to bankruptcy, and stiff competition from Direct-to-Home Satellite TV providers such as [[Cignal]], [[Sky Direct]] and [[G Sat]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.facebook.com/DTVPilipinas/videos/2277361448956053/|title=Dream Satellite TV public service announcement|publisher=DTV Pilipinas FB Page|date=December 29, 2017|accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref>
==Hardware== ===Receivers=== Early receivers were made by Nokia (Nokia MediaMaster 8830S/8630S), Digital AllWorld (DAW951 and DAW-SNA4400), ViStar and Crystal. Those receivers were already phased out by Dream (except for DAW-SNA4400 and Crystal), due to the lack of Nagravision 3/Conax support. The later receivers, such as Homecast eM-152USNA, KAON K-270 and the Arion AF-5102S (both of them were still offered by Dream). Both of these receivers are only capable of receiving standard definition broadcasts.
==Smart cards== At the time when the first DVB-version of Nagravision is not yet introduced, Dream Satellite used Conax CAS3 for the main broadcast until they switch to Nagravision 2 and Conax CAS7 encryption on 2006. In 2009, following the Dish Network anti-piracy upgrade, a conditional access swap to the smart card has been completed. This also made the smart card system transitioned to Nagravision Merlin and Conax CAS7.5.
==Status of competition and controversy== Dream Satellite TV filed a complaint with the [[National Telecommunications Commission (Philippines)|National Telecommunications Commission]] (NTC) against Global Broadcasting and Multimedia, Inc. ([[G Sat]]) for offering A DTH service in the Philippines without a franchise and a license from Philippine authorities, namely the Philippine Congress for a broadcast franchise and the NTC for a Certificate of Public Convenience.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://abs-cbnnews.com/business/01/19/09/dreamtv-operator-seeks-regulator-help-over-satellite-tv-dispute | title=Dream TV operator seeks regulator help over satellite TV dispute | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=January 1, 2009 | accessdate=November 11, 2013}}</ref> Aside from Dream, the Lopez-owned [[Sky Cable Corporation]] also filed a similar complaint against GBMI. It argued that GBMI's illegal entry into the industry will result in the unnecessary duplication of an existing service that existing cable TV and DTH-TV service providers already adequately provide.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yehey.com/finance/level3.aspx?id=221433&p=3 | title=SkyCable sues DTH competitor | publisher=''Yehey!'' | date=January 19, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090205232746/http://dream.com.ph/ Dream Satellite TV official website] *[http://www.dreamsatellite.com/ Dream Satellite TV Shanghai Service Center official website] *{{Facebook}} *{{Twitter}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} [[File:ECF RGB.jpg|thumb|256x256px]] The '''European Climate Foundation''' (founded 2008)<ref>[https://europeanclimate.org/mission/vision/ https://europeanclimate.org/mission/vision/]</ref> is an international organisation whose aims are to promote [[climate and energy]] policies that it says would greatly reduce [[Europe]]'s [[greenhouse gas emissions]] and to help Europe play a stronger international leadership role in mitigating [[climate change]].
==General== According to the group, key elements of a [[sustainable energy]] future include: *A substantial increase in [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] *A successful transition from conventional to [[renewable energy]] *Maintenance of the earth’s ecological systems and the life-supporting services they provide *Equitable distribution of [[energy services]] to different segments of the population, both internationally and within nations.
The European Climate Foundation is funded by the [[Nationale Postcode Loterij]], [[Lisbet Rausing|The Arcadia Fund]], [[The Children's Investment Fund Foundation]], The ClimateWorks Foundation, [[John MacBain|The McCall MacBain Foundation]], Oak Foundation, [[Petter Stordalen|The Stordalen Foundation]] and [[The William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]].
==Funding== The European Climate Foundation established [[CarbonBrief]] in the end of 2010.<ref name="Drum1">{{cite web|url=https://www.thedrum.com/opinion/2017/06/15/how-twitter-and-carbon-brief-are-helping-climate-change-scientists-fight-donald|title=How Twitter and Carbon Brief are helping climate change scientists fight Donald Trump online|year=2017|work=The Drum}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.europeanclimate.org European Climate Foundation website]
{{Europe-stub}}
[[Category:Climate change organizations]]

page.title: Foreign Trade Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Foreign Trade Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea | logo = | type = [[Bank]] | industry = [[Foreign-exchange reserves]] | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = FTB Building, Jungsong-dong, Seungri Street, [[Central District (Pyongyang)|Central District]] | hq_location_city = [[Pyongyang]] | hq_location_country = [[North Korea]]<ref name="Martino2013">{{cite book|editor-last=Martino|editor-first=John|title=Worldwide Government Directory with Intergovernmental Organizations 2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CQWhAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA891|year=2013|publisher=Sage Reference|location=Los Angeles|isbn=978-1-4522-9937-2|page=891}}</ref> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = O Kwang-chol (President)<ref name="Martino2013"/> | products = | owner = [[Government of North Korea]]<!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | module = {{Infobox Korean name | hangul = 조선무역은행 | hanja = 朝鮮貿易銀行 | rr = Joseon muyeog eunhaeng | mr = Chosŏn muyŏk ŭnhaeng | koreanipa = | context = north | child = yes}} | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} The '''Foreign Trade Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea''' ('''Joson Trade Bank''') is [[North Korea]]'s primary [[Foreign-exchange reserves|foreign exchange]] [[bank]], and is owned and run by the [[North Korean government]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl1876.aspx|title=Treasury Sanctions Bank and Official Linked to North Korean Weapons of Mass Destruction Programs|publisher=US Department of the Treasury}}</ref>
On March 11, 2013, the United States designated the bank as falling under US [[executive order]] 13382, which applies to "proliferators of weapons of mass destruction and their supporters". The order freezes all assets, and prohibits any transactions between US entities and the bank.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/t/isn/c22080.htm|title=Executive Order 13382}}</ref>
On May 7, 2013, the state-controlled [[Bank of China]] announced that they would stop all dealings with the Foreign Trade Bank. China has in the past been reluctant to sanction North Korea, even though China has been very unsatisfied with North Korea's aggressive stance and pursuit of nuclear weapons. Stopping the dealing with the Foreign Trade Bank is seen as a significant signal by China to put pressure on North Korea.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/08/world/asia/china-cuts-ties-with-north-korean-bank.html|title=China Cuts Ties With Key North Korean Bank|publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
On August 5, 2017 the [[UN Security Council]] adopted [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2371|Resolution 2371]] expanding financial sanctions<ref name="UNSC Res 1718 (2006)"/> to include the bank.<ref name="S/RES/2371"/><ref name="NYT Aug 5"/><ref name="US mission to UN August 5 2017"/>
After [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2094|UN Security Council Resolution 2094]] was adopted in March 2013, several Chinese banks will not deal with the Foreign Trade Bank.<ref name="Beijing orders banks to close accounts for North Koreans">{{cite web | url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01500&num=14709 | title=Beijing orders banks to close accounts for North Koreans | publisher=Daily NK | date=2017-09-09 | accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref>
The United States Department of the Treasury has designated Dandong Zhongsheng Industry & Trade Co Ltd and Korea Ungum Corporation as FTB [[Front organization|front companies]], and sanctioned the Moscow-based Agrosoyuz Commercial Bank for facilitating transactions for the FTB.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-Relations/US-hits-Russian-bank-with-sanctions-for-North-Korea-related-activity |publisher=''[[Nikkei Asian Review]]'' |title=US hits Russian bank with sanctions for North Korea-related activity |author=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|North Korea|Business and economics}} *[[Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] *[[Ministry of External Economic Relations]] *[[Economy of North Korea]]
== References == {{reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name="UNSC Res 1718 (2006)">{{cite web | url= http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/RES/1718%20%282006%29 |title=UN Security Council Resolution 1718 |author=[[United Nations Security Council]] | date= October 14, 2006 | publisher= [[United Nations]] | location= | accessdate= August 20, 2017 | archiveurl= | archivedate= July 30, 2017 |deadurl=no |quote=(d) All Member States shall, in accordance with their respective legal processes, freeze immediately the funds, other financial assets and economic resources which are on their territories at the date of the adoption of this resolution or at any time thereafter, that are owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, by the persons or entities designated by the Committee or by the Security Council as being engaged in or providing support for, including through other illicit means, DPRK’s nuclear-related, other weapons of mass destruction-related and ballistic missile related programmes, or by persons or entities acting on their behalf or at their direction, and ensure that any funds, financial assets or economic resources are prevented from being made available by their nationals or by any persons or entities within their territories, to or for the benefit of such persons or entities; }}</ref>
<ref name="S/RES/2371">{{UN doc |docid=S/RES/2371 |body=S |session= |type=R |resolution_number= 2371|document_number= |title=Resolution 2371 (2017) - Adopted by the Security Council at its 8019th meeting, on 5 August 2017 |page= |pages= |date=5 August 2017 |year= |meeting=8019 |meetingtime= |speakername= |speakernation= |language= |accessdate=}}</ref>
<ref name="NYT Aug 5">{{cite news |title=U.N. Security Council imposes punishing new sanctions on North Korea |first1=Rick |last1=Gladstone|first2= |last2=|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/05/world/asia/north-korea-sanctions-united-nations.html |newspaper= The New York Times |location=USA |date=August 5, 2017 |accessdate= August 8, 2017|page= }}</ref>
<ref name="US mission to UN August 5 2017">{{cite web | url= https://usun.state.gov/remarks/7924 |title=FACT SHEET: Resolution 2371 (2017) Strengthening Sanctions on North Korea |author=[[United States Mission to the United Nations]] | date= August 5, 2017 | publisher= [[United States Department of State]]| location= U.S.A. | accessdate= August 20, 2017 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170819233305/https://usun.state.gov/remarks/7924 | archivedate= August 19, 2017 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
}}
==External links== *[http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl1876.aspx Treasury Sanctions Bank and Official Linked to North Korean Weapons of Mass Destruction Programs] - US Department of the Treasury

revision.text:
{|{{Infobox ship begin |display title=ital }} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Bell HD-4.jpg |Ship caption=''HD-4'' at [[Baddeck, Nova Scotia]], in 1919 }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=Canada |Ship flag= |Ship name=''HD-4'' |Ship namesake=Hydrodome number 4 |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder=[[Alexander Graham Bell]] |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1919 |Ship completed= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Baddeck, Nova Scotia]] |Ship identification= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} |}
'''''HD-4''''' or '''''Hydrodome number 4''''' was an early research [[hydrofoil]] watercraft developed by the scientist [[Alexander Graham Bell]]. It was designed and built at the [[Bell Boatyard]] on Bell's [[Beinn Bhreagh, Nova Scotia|Beinn Bhreagh]] estate near [[Baddeck, Nova Scotia]]. In 1919, it set a [[water speed record|world marine speed record]] of {{convert|70.86|mph|km/h}}.
== History ==
The March 1906 ''[[Scientific American]]'' article by American pioneer William E. Meacham, explained the basic principle of [[hydrofoil]]s and [[Hydroplane (boat)|hydroplane]]s. Bell considered the invention of the hydroplane a very significant achievement. Baldwin studied the work of the Italian inventor [[Enrico Forlanini]] and began testing models based on his designs, which led them to the development of hydrofoil watercraft. Based on information gained from that article he began to sketch concepts of what is now called a hydrofoil boat. Bell, with his chief engineer [[Frederick W. Baldwin|Casey Baldwin]], began hydrofoil experiments in the summer of 1908. During Bell's world tour of 1910–1911, Bell and Baldwin met with Forlanini in Italy, where they rode in his hydrofoil boat over [[Lake Maggiore]]. Baldwin described it as being as smooth as flying.
On returning to Bell's large laboratory and boatyard at his [[Beinn Bhreagh, Nova Scotia|Beinn Bhreagh]] estate near [[Baddeck, Nova Scotia]], they experimented with a number of designs, culminating in ''HD-4''. In 1913, Dr. Bell hired Walter Pinaud, a Sydney yacht designer and builder as well as the proprietor of Pinaud's Yacht Yard in [[Westmount, Nova Scotia|Westmount]] to work on the pontoons of ''HD-4''. Pinaud soon took over the [[Bell Boatyard]] at Beinn Bhreagh. Pinaud's experience in boat-building enabled him to make useful design changes to ''HD-4''. After the [[First World War]], work began again on ''HD-4''. Bell's report to the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] permitted him to obtain two {{convert|350|bhp|kW}} [[Liberty L-12|Liberty V-12]] engines in July 1919.
Bell and associate [[Frederick W. Baldwin|Frederick W. "Casey" Baldwin]] began hydrofoil experimentation in the summer of 1908, as a possible aid to airplane takeoff from water. On September 9, 1919, on the [[Bras d'Or Lakes]], at Baddeck, ''HD-4'' set a [[water speed record|world marine speed record]] of {{convert|70.86|mph|km/h}}, that stood for almost a year until being beaten by [[Gar Wood]] in ''Miss America''.<ref>http://www.h1unlimited.com/2009/03/the-gar-wood-story/</ref>
== Museum display ==
[[File:MuseeBaddeck.JPG|thumb|''HD-4'' hydrofoil at the [[Alexander Graham Bell National Historic Site|Alexander Graham Bell museum]]]]
A full-scale replica of Bell's ''HD-4'' is viewable at the [[Alexander Graham Bell National Historic Site|Alexander Graham Bell museum]] in [[Baddeck, Nova Scotia]], Canada.
== See also ==
* [[Bras d'Or (R-103)]], a small experimental hydrofoil built for the Royal Canadian Navy (RCN) during the 1950s * [[HMCS Bras d'Or (FHE 400)]], a hydrofoil that served in the Canadian Forces from 1968 to 1971, and the fastest unarmed warship in the world for several years
== References ==
; Citations
{{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{more footnotes|date=May 2012}}

page.title: Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=December 2015}} '''Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue''' is a report issued by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]]'s [[Centre for Tax Policy and Administration]].
In the report, the OECD groups countries into three categories: member country preferential regimes, [[tax havens]], and non-member economies, and establishes criteria for identifying each.<ref> “More Information on the Harmful Tax practices Work,” <u>OECD Centre for Tax Policy and Administration</u>, OECD.org, 17 July 2007 <http://www.oecd.org/document/49/0,3343,en_2649_33745_33995569_1_1_1_1,00.html>.</ref> Tax havens are characterised by having only nominal or no taxes, impeding the free [[exchange of information]] on taxpayers with other governments through administrative practices or laws, non-[[Transparency (social)|transparency]], and a lack of substantial activities.<ref><u>Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue</u> (Paris: OECD Publications, 1998) 22, OECD.org, 17 July 2007 < http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/33/1/1904184.pdf >.</ref> Harmful preferential regimes, whether in member or non-member countries, are identified by four main traits. Like tax havens, their legal or administrative systems hamper the exchange of information and create an absence of transparency, and have effectively low or no taxes. Finally, the regime may partially isolate itself from the taxpayers and bear little to none of the tax burden, a practice known as “ring-fencing.”<ref><u>Harmful Tax Competition: An Emerging Global Issue</u> (Paris: OECD Publications, 1998) 26, OECD.org, 17 July 2007 < http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/33/1/1904184.pdf >.</ref>
==See also== *[[Tax competition]] *[[Tax haven]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:International taxation]] [[Category:Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] [[Category:Tax avoidance]]

{{more footnotes|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox organization | logo = IOCDF logo.jpg | type = Registered non-profit | key_people = Jeff Szymanski, PhD (Executive Director) | footnotes = | name = The International OCD Foundation | founded_date = 1986 | founders = Wayne Goodman, Patricia Perkins, Frances Sydney | location = Boston, MA | origins = | product = | focus = Obsessive compulsive disorder | method = | num_employees = 13 | homepage = {{url|https://iocdf.org}} | dissolved = |board_of_directors = Susan Boaz (President); Denis Asselin (Vice President); Ron Prevost (Treasurer); Denise Egan Stack, LMHC (Secretary); David Calusdian; Diane Davey, RN; Michael Jenike, MD; Elizabeth McIngvale, PhD, LMSW; Paul A. Mueller; Michael Stack, CFA; Jo-Ann Winston; Joy Kant (Emeritus); Patricia Perkins, JD (Emeritus) }} The '''International OCD Foundation''' is a [[non-profit organization]] that aims to "help everyone affected by obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) and related disorders to live full and productive lives".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://iocdf.org/about/|title=About Us|date=11 June 2012|publisher=|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref>
==History and overview==
Best estimates are that about 1 in 100 adults – or between 2 and 3 million adults in the [[United States]] – currently have [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]] or OCD.<ref>{{cite web|title=Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder|url=http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications/anxiety-disorders/obsessive-compulsive-disorder.shtml|work=National Institute of Mental Health|accessdate=17 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Ruscio|first=AM|author2=Stein DJ |author3=Chiu WT |author4=Kessler RC |title=The epidemiology of obsessive-compulsive disorder in the National Comorbidity Survey Replication|journal=Molecular Psychiatry|pmid=18725912|pmc=2797569|year=2010|volume=15|issue=1|pages=53–63|doi=10.1038/mp.2008.94}}</ref> There are also at least 1 in 200 – or 500,000 – kids and teens that have OCD. That means four or five kids with OCD are likely to be enrolled in any average size elementary school. In a medium to large high school, there could be 20 students struggling with the challenges caused by OCD.<ref>{{cite book|last=March|first=J.|title=Talking Back to OCD|year=2007|publisher=The Guilford Press|pages=10–11|author2=Benton, C}}</ref>
In 1986, the International OCD Foundation – originally the Obsessive Compulsive Foundation – was created by a small, dedicated group of individuals who had OCD. They were all participating in research studies at the Connecticut Mental Health Center<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ct.gov/dmhas/cwp/view.asp?a=2906&q=334596|title=The Connecticut Mental Health Center}}</ref> in New Haven, CT. The principal investigator on the studies was Wayne Goodman, M.D., a junior faculty psychiatrist who started the OCD program at Yale University School of Medicine during his residency training there. It was also Dr. Goodman's idea to bring the group together.
Originally the plan had been to just form a self-help group, but as soon as they got together they realized that there was a great deal of work to be done to defeat OCD. So in November 1986, they started the Foundation as a way to get the word out about OCD and its treatment. This was the first time for many of them to find some relief from OCD and to meet others who were also suffering from OCD. Being together inspired them to start working together to help others suffering from OCD.
Before the first meeting, some of the members sent a letter to ABC's [[20/20]] describing OCD and suggesting that the producers do a segment on it. As soon as the group got together in 1986, they drafted a brochure explaining OCD with the help of Dr. Goodman and put together notices giving the locations of the 22 locations around the country where the trials were taking place.
In March 1987, John Stoessel of ABC's 20/20 featured a segment with Dr. Goodman and one of his patients, another Foundation founder. The reaction was immediate and overwhelming. The network television show opened the door for thousands of people to step forward and put a name on their illness. The small corps of founders were flooded with 20,000 inquiries in the days following the 20/20 segment. While they recognized their own need for support and more information, they were not prepared for the tremendous need throughout the country. A PO box, a small grant for long distance phone calls, and weekly meetings were used to answer all inquiries and to match patients with the 22 clinical trial sites throughout the country.
Within the year, the Obsessive Compulsive Foundation – now the International OCD Foundation – was formalized as a not-for-profit corporation and the group began mailing out the locations of the 22 sites where treatment was being provided, its new brochure and a newsletter to spread the word on OCD and its possible treatments. A Scientific Advisory Board, composed of researchers and treatment providers from the 22 clinical trial sites, was organized and led by Dr. Goodman.
By 1988, the Foundation was ready to bring information to the psychotherapy community. Board members set up an information booth and attended the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. The founders attended other meetings and conventions, and they realized the need to provide information not only to people seeking treatment, but also to the mental health community so that treatment was appropriate and accessible.
In 1989, the Foundation hired its first paid staff. Funding came first from pharmaceutical companies, but membership grew rapidly providing operating funds and a national network. The Foundation provided guidance on creating OCD support groups and 52 were established across the country.
The clarity of the vision of the founding members facilitated the depth and breadth of the Foundation's growth. Within a decade, the Foundation established the Behavior Therapy Training Institutes (BTTI)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocfoundation.org/BTTI.aspx|title=Behavior Therapy Training Institute}}</ref> which train therapists across the country, research awards for studies on OCD, an Annual Conference, publications and videos, comprehensive educational materials about OCD in children for teachers, a website and a bi-monthly newsletter.
==Present activities== In 2007, the Board of Directors voted to move the Foundation from [[New Haven|New Haven, CT]] to [[Boston|Boston, MA]]. With a 100% turn over in staff, this marked a significant transition for the 20-plus year old organization. Today, the Foundation has 12 individuals serving on the Board of Directors, 9 full-time paid staff, 47 Scientific Advisory Board members, 22 affiliates, 6,000 members/financial supporters, 32 Institutional Members and an operating budget of 1 million dollars. Funding for the Foundation's programs come from donations, membership fees, and grants. The International OCD Foundation no longer accepts money from pharmaceutical or biomedical companies.
The mission of the organization at its founding is much the same as today: education, awareness, training, accessing resources and research. In 2009, the IOCDF hired [[Teak Media]] to help promote awareness about OCD and effective treatments. The collaboration between Teak and the IOCDF resulted in almost 100 media hits in newspapers, online, in magazines, and has been featured on [[Nightline]] and [[CNN]]. Teak regularly accesses the IOCDF's Speakers Bureau. The Speakers Bureau members include people with OCD who understand firsthand the challenges of this disorder in addition to well-known clinical and research experts who have treated people with OCD.
Late in 2009, a newly designed website was launched with links to social networking sites including [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and [[YouTube]]. The website also continues to be a source of information about OCD and related disorders, effective treatment, a database of 250 support groups, 1,000 treatment providers, and 30-plus OCD intensive treatment programs. Additionally, in Spring of 2010, the IOCDF launched a virtual Hoarding Center. In 2010, the Foundation hosted its 17th Annual Conference. Over 1,000 individuals attended this year including those with OCD, their family members, treatment professionals and researchers. The organization continues to distribute quarterly newsletters, provide three Behavior Therapy Training Institutes around the country annually, and continues to fund OCD related research.
Additional initiatives the IOCDF has prioritized this year include revamping and updating the “OCD in the Classroom” program, launching a Pediatric OCD website, promoting awareness through OCD Awareness Week events, and building and developing international resources for individuals suffering with OCD around the world.
==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://iocdf.org International OCD Foundation]
{{Obsessive–compulsive disorder}}

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{Eastern name order|Kim Ji-hee}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Ji Hee Kim | birth_name = | nationality = [[South Korea]]n | fields = | workplaces = Korean Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) | alma_mater = BSc [[Mokpo National University]]
PhD [[Seoul National University]] | awards = KOPRI Medal (2005 & 2010)
Ministerial Award of Land Transport and Maritime Affairs (2012) | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes | hangul = {{linktext|김|지|희}} | hanja = ! | mr = Kim Chihŭi | rr = Gim Jihui}} }} '''Ji Hee Kim''' is an [[Antarctic]] researcher, best known for being the Principal Investigator for comprehensive [[environmental monitoring]] and construction of the long term environmental database at South Korea's [[King Sejong Station]]. ==Early life and education== Kim received her BSc biology at [[Mokpo National University]] in 1991 and her MSc biology at [[Seoul National University]] in 1993, and PhD at the same university in 2000.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kopri.re.kr/www/about/kopri_searchstaff/staff.do|title=극지연구소|publisher=Korean Polar Research Institute|access-date=2016-06-19}} She started her research work at the Korean Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) in 1998 before she completed her PhD. She has been a key member of the polar ecology laboratory at KOPRI.{{Cite web|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=104&oid=086&aid=0002040947|script-title=ko:[제5회 장보고대상 후보]⑧김지희 극지연구소 선임연구원|trans-title=Candidates for 5th Jang Bogo Award, No. 8: Kim Ji-hee, Korean Polar Research Institute senior researcher|work=Naeil Sinmun|date=2011-03-09|access-date=2016-06-19}} ==Career and impact== Kim has led many projects at KOPRI, particularly after the construction of [[Jang Bogo Station]], South Korea's second Antarctic research station. Kim was a key member of the expedition team searching for the proper site and later Principal Investigator for the preparation for [http://eng.kopri.re.kr/home_e/contents/e_3330000/JangBogoStation.cms the Comprehensive Environmental Evaluation].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnews.co.kr/uhtml/read.jsp?idxno=201207260909551180678|title=<인터뷰> 극지연구소 대륙기지건설단 김지희 박사|trans-title=Interview: Dr. Kim Ji-hee of the Korean Polar Research Institute continental base construction team|work=Geonseol Gyeongje [Construction Business]|date=2012-07-26|access-date=2016-06-19}} She is the Principal Investigator for comprehensive environmental monitoring and construction of a long term environmental database in the [[King Sejong Station]].{{Cite web|url=http://m.blog.daum.net/buenita47/9656|title=12 여성 과학자, 남극에 가다!|website=Daum Blog|trans-title=12 women scientists, go to Antarctica!|access-date=2016-06-19}} ==Awards and honours== Kim was awarded a KOPRI medal in 2005 and 2010.{{Cite web|url=https://eng.kiost.ac/kordi_web/brochure/2005_E.pdf |title=Annual Report |last= |first= |date=2005 |website= |publisher=Korea Ocean Research & Development Institute |access-date= }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web|url=http://eng.kopri.re.kr/www/about/kopri_brochure/annual_report_2010.pdf|title=Annual Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Korea Polar Research Institute|publication-date=2010|access-date=}} She was also awarded the Ministerial Award of Land Transport and Maritime Affairs in 2012.{{Cite web|url=http://eng.kopri.re.kr/www/about/kopri_brochure/annual_report_eng_2012.pdf|title=Annual Report|last=|first=|date=2012|website=|publisher=Korean Polar Research Institute|access-date=}} == Selected works == * Y-J Jung, Y M Lee, K Baek, C Y Hwang, Y Cho, S G Hong, J H Kim, H K Lee 2015. ''Algibacter psychrophilus'' sp. nov., a psychrophilic bacterium isolated from marine sediment. International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology 65(6) 1735-1740.{{Cite journal|last=Jung|first=You-Jung|last2=Lee|first2=Yung Mi|last3=Baek|first3=Kiwoon|last4=Hwang|first4=Chung Yeon|last5=Cho|first5=Yirang|last6=Hong|first6=Soon Gyu|last7=Kim|first7=Ji Hee|last8=Lee|first8=Hong Kum|date=2015-01-01|title=Algibacter psychrophilus sp. nov., a psychrophilic bacterium isolated from marine sediment|url=http://ijs.microbiologyresearch.org/content/journal/ijsem/10.1099/ijs.0.000168|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|volume=65|issue=6|pages=1735–1740|doi=10.1099/ijs.0.000168|pmid=25740931}} * K Baek, Y M Lee, C Y Hwang, H Park, Y-J Jung, M-K Kim, S G Hong, J H Kim, H K Lee. 2015. Psychroserpens janbogonensis sp. nov., apsychrophilic bacterium isolated from Antarctic marine sediment. International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology. 65(1): 183-188.{{Cite journal|last=Baek|first=Kiwoon|last2=Lee|first2=Yung Mi|last3=Hwang|first3=Chung Yeon|last4=Park|first4=Hyun|last5=Jung|first5=You-Jung|last6=Kim|first6=Mi-Kyeong|last7=Hong|first7=Soon Gyu|last8=Kim|first8=Ji Hee|last9=Lee|first9=Hong Kum|date=2015-01-01|title=Psychroserpens jangbogonensis sp. nov., a psychrophilic bacterium isolated from Antarctic marine sediment|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|volume=65|issue=Pt 1|pages=183–188|doi=10.1099/ijs.0.069740-0|issn=1466-5034|pmid=25316694}} * M Kim, A Cho, H S Lim, S G Hong, J H Kim, J Lee, T Choi, T S Ahn, O-S Kim. 2015. Journal of Phycology Vol. 43. 1310-1319.{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Ji Hee|last2=Guiry|first2=Michael D.|last3=Oak|first3=Jung Hyun|last4=Choi|first4=Do-Sung|last5=Kang|first5=Sung-Ho|last6=Chung|first6=Hosung|last7=Choi|first7=Han-Gu|date=2007-12-01|title=Phylogenetic relationships within the tribe Janieae (Corallinales, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morphological data: a reappraisal of Jania1|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1529-8817.2007.00410.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Phycology|language=en|volume=43|issue=6|pages=1310–1319|doi=10.1111/j.1529-8817.2007.00410.x|issn=1529-8817}} * J.H. Arctics|url=http://agris.fao.org/agris-search/search.do?recordID=KR2007002962|journal=Journal of Plant Biotechnology|language=Korean|issn=1598-6365}} * J.H. Kim et al. 2006. Lichen flora around the Korean Antarctic scientific station, King George Island, Antarctic. Microbiology. Vol. 30, 903-916.{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Ji Hee|last2=Ahn|first2=In-Young|last3=Hong|first3=Soon Gyu|last4=Andreev|first4=Mikhail|last5=Lim|first5=Kwang-Mi|last6=Oh|first6=Mi Jin|last7=Koh|first7=Young Jin|last8=Hur|first8=Jae-Seoun|date=2006-10-01|title=Lichen flora around the Korean Antarctic Scientific Station, King George Island, Antarctic|journal=Journal of Microbiology (Seoul, Korea)|volume=44|issue=5|pages=480–491|issn=1225-8873|pmid=17082741}} ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==External links== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Ji Hee}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South Korean women scientists]] [[Category:Seoul National University alumni]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:South Korean scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:21st-century South Korean scientists]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Other uses|Jinx (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jinx | image = Jinx 25012013 Noc muzeja 02 roberta f.jpg | alt = | caption = Jinx | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] | genre = [[Pop music]] | years_active = {{Start date|1994}}–{{end date|2002}}
{{Start date|2007}}–present | label = [[Aquarius Records (Croatia)|Aquarius]], [[Dallas Records]], Hayat Production | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|www.myspace.com/jinxhr}} | current_members = [[Coco Mosquito]]
Jadranka Bastajić
Berko Muratović
Mr. Goody
Igor Pavlica
Adam Matijašević | past_members = }} '''Jinx''' is a Croatian [[Pop music|pop]] band from Zagreb which was formed in 1993. They began their career under the name "High Jinx" coming from a concert in a Zagreb night-club Saloon.[http://www.mtv.com.hr/artisti/jinx Jinx – Artisti — MTV Hrvatska] {{hr icon}} The members of Jinx are guitarist [[Coco Mosquito]], vocalist Jadranka Bastajic Yaya, drummer Berko Muratovic, keyboardist Mr. Goody, trumpet player Igor Pavlica and bassist Adam Matijasevic. Former members of the band are Goony, Kiky the Kid, bassist Samir Kadribasic, trumpet player Rudi and saxophone player Jordes. The prefix "High" was dropped in 1995, since all fans who attended their first gigs referred to them solely as Jinx. Their first album, ''Sextasy'', was released in English. Berko and Samir joined the band in 1996. In 1997, Jinx signed their first record contract with [[Aquarius Records (Croatia)|Aquarius Records]] and released their second album called ''Second Hand''. In 2001, Percussionist Boris Popov joined the band. Jinx disbanded in 2002 and made a comeback in 2007 with the album ''Na zapadu'' (In the West), having signed with [[Dallas Records]]. ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''Sextasy'' (1995; re-released in 2000) * ''Second Hand'' (1997) * ''Pompei – Ljetna ploča katastrofe'' (1999) * ''Avantura počinje'' (2001) * ''Retro/Best of Jinx'' (2002; compilation) * ''Na zapadu'' (2007) * ''Diksilend'' (2010) ===Singles=== * ''Smijem se'' (1997) * ''Bye bye baby bye'' (1999) * ''Koliko suza'' (1999) * ''Tamo gdje je sve po mom'' (2001) * ''Na čemu si ti'' (2007) * ''Jesmo li dobro?'' (2016) ==Awards== * 1998 – Radio France International, Bucharest, best new artist * 2002 – [[Porin (music award)|Porin]] Award, Hit of the Year * 2011 – [[Porin (music award)|Porin]] Award, Best Pop Album ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.myspace.com/jinxhr Official MySpace] * [http://www.new.facebook.com/pages/JINX/36666147192 Official Facebook] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jinx}} [[Category:Croatian pop music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1994]] [[Category:Hayat Production artists]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Croatia]] {{Croatia-stub}}

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Lhop
(Doya) |image = |caption = |population = 2,500 (1993){{cite web|url=http://repository.forcedmigration.org/pdf/?pid=fmo:3003 |format=PDF |last=van Driem |first=George L. |authorlink=George van Driem |title=Language Policy in Bhutan |publisher=[[School of Oriental and African Studies|SOAS]] |location=[[London]] |year=1993 |accessdate=2011-01-18}} |popplace = Southwestern [[Bhutan]] ([[Samtse District]]) |langs = [[Lhokpu language|Lhokpu]], [[Dzongkha]] |rels = [[Buddhism]], [[Bön]] |related-c = [[Lepcha people|Lepcha]] }} The '''Lhop''' or '''Doya people''' are a little-known tribe of southwest [[Bhutan]]. The Bhutanese believe them to be the [[indigenous peoples|aboriginal]] inhabitants of the country. The Lhop are found in the low valleys of [[Dorokha gewog , Samtse]] and near [[Phuntsholing]] in the [[Duars]]. The dress of the Lhop resembles the [[Lepcha people|Lepcha]], but they bear little similarity with the [[Bhutia]] in the North and the [[Toto tribe|Toto]] in the west. The Doya trace their descent [[matrilineality|matrilineally]], marry their [[cross cousin]]s, and embalm the deceased who are then placed in a foetal position in a circular sarcophagus above the ground. They follow a blend of [[Tibetan Buddhism]] mixed with [[animism]]. ==See also== *[[Ethnic groups in Bhutan]] *[[Sharchop people|Sharchop]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.raonline.ch/pages/bt/peop/btpeop_lhop01.html RAOnline Bhutan: The Lhop] {{Bhutanese society}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Bhutan]] {{Bhutan-stub}} {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox television| | show_name = Root Into Europe | image = | size = | caption = | runtime = 60mins | creator = [[William Donaldson]] |director=Mark Chapman |producer=Mark Chapman

[[Pat Heywood]] | network = [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] | company =Aspect Film & TV for [[ITV Central|Central Independent Television]] | first_aired = {{Start date|df=yes|1992|5|17}} | last_aired =
{{End date|df=yes|1992|6|14}} | num_series = 1 | num_episodes = 5 }} '''''Root Into Europe''''' is an [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] comedy-drama based on the character from [[William Donaldson]]'s book ''[[The Henry Root Letters]]''. Five episodes Written by Donaldson and Mark Chapman and produced by Aspect Film & TV for [[ITV Central|Central Independent Television]], were first broadcast in May and June 1992. The series starred [[George Cole (actor)|George Cole]] as Henry Root, and [[Pat Heywood]] as his wife, Muriel. Henry Root, a fish dealer who disapproves of the impending [[European Union]], declares himself England's 'European regulator' in a letter to the [[British Prime Minister]], then [[John Major]]. He takes his wife Muriel ([[Pat Heywood]]) on a tour of Europe to represent English values to mainland Europe. His adventures are captured on a [[camcorder]] by his wife to be sent to the BBC upon his return for a future documentary, which one expects will never be made. The episodes bring him to [[France]], [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[Germany]], [[Belgium]] and [[The Netherlands]]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314040857/http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/articles/r/rootintoeurope_1299002698.shtml Comedy Guide - ''Root Into Europe''] at [[bbc.co.uk]] * {{IMDb title|id=0103527|title=Root Into Europe}} *[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/series/19985 BFI database] [[Category:ITV television dramas]] [[Category:1992 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:1992 British television programme endings]] [[Category:1990s British drama television series]] [[Category:Europe in fiction]] [[Category:Paris in fiction]] [[Category:Madrid in fiction]] [[Category:Rome in fiction]] [[Category:Berlin in fiction]] [[Category:Brussels in fiction]] [[Category:Amsterdam in fiction]] [[Category:Television shows set in Europe]] [[Category:Television shows set in France]] [[Category:Television shows set in Belgium]] [[Category:Television shows set in Italy]] [[Category:Television shows set in Germany]] [[Category:Television shows set in Spain]] [[Category:Television shows set in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Television programmes produced by Central Independent Television]] [[Category:Television series by ITV Studios]] {{UK-tv-prog-stub}}

'''Squeaky Dolphin''' is a program developed by the [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ), a British [[intelligence agency|intelligence]] and [[security agency|security]] organization, to collect and analyze data from [[social media]] networks. The program was first revealed to the general public on [[NBC]] on 27 January 2014 based on documents previously leaked by [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name=NBCJan14>{{cite news|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2014/01/27/22469304-snowden-docs-reveal-british-spies-snooped-on-youtube-and-facebook?lite|title=Snowden docs reveal British spies snooped on YouTube and Facebook|date=27 January 2014|publisher=NBC News|author1=Richard Esposito |author2=Matthew Cole |author3=Mark Schone |author4=Glenn Greenwald |accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref>
== Scope of surveillance == According to a document of the GCHQ dated August 2012, the program enables broad, [[Real-time data|real-time]] surveillance of the following items:
* [[YouTube]] video views<ref name=NBCJan14/><ref name=zdnet>{{cite web|last=Dignan|first=Larry|title=Snowden's Squeaky Dolphin leak: Brits spy on YouTube, Facebook behavior|url=http://www.zdnet.com/snowdens-squeaky-dolphin-leak-brits-spy-on-youtube-facebook-behavior-7000025641/|publisher=[[ZDNet]]|accessdate=28 January 2014|date=28 January 2014}}</ref> * The [[Like button]] on [[Facebook]].<ref name=zdnet/> Facebook has since then encrypted the data.<ref name=NBCJan14/> * [[Blogger (service)|Blogspot/Blogger]] visits<ref name=NBCJan14/><ref name=zdnet/> * [[Twitter]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Kelion |first=Leo |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-25927844 |title=BBC News - Snowden leaks: GCHQ 'spied on Facebook and YouTube' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> which has however encrypted its communications since this presentation was made<ref>{{cite web|author=Matt Swider |url=http://www.techradar.com/news/internet/web/youtube-facebook-data-caught-up-in-uk-s-squeaky-dolphin-spy-program-1219229 |title=YouTube, Facebook data caught up in UK's 'Squeaky Dolphin' spy program | News |publisher=TechRadar |date= |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
The program can be supplemented with commercially available analytic software to determine which videos are popular among residents of specific cities.<ref name=NBCJan14/> The dashboard software chosen was made by [[Splunk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcpro.co.uk/blogs/2014/01/28/splunk-and-the-squeaky-dolphin-when-big-data-goes-rogue/ |title=Splunk and the Squeaky Dolphin: when Big Data goes rogue | PC Pro blog |publisher=Pcpro.co.uk |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
The presentation, which was originally shown to an [[NSA]] audience and was made public by the NBC, contains a note saying the program was "Not interested in individuals just broad trends!". However, "according to other Snowden documents" obtained by NBC, in 2010, "GCHQ exploited unencrypted data from Twitter to identify specific users around the world and target them with propaganda."<ref name=NBCJan14/>
== See also == {{Portal|Mass surveillance}} * [[Five Eyes]] * [[MUSCULAR]] — program for capturing Google and Yahoo private cloud data
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/msnbc/Sections/NEWS/snowden_youtube_nbc_document.pdf Slides released by NBC]
[[Category:Government Communications Headquarters operations]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:National Security Agency]] [[Category:Surveillance scandals]] [[Category:Social media]]

Among the [[Ket people]] of [[Siberia]], '''Tomam''' was the goddess of migratory birds. She is associated with the south, warmth, and the northern migration of birds that accompanies the warmer months. In the autumn southward migrating birds are considered to be returning to "Mother Tomam".<ref>{{cite book|title=The Deer Goddess of Ancient Siberia|author=Esther Jacobson|page=200|publisher=Brill|date=1993|isbn=9789004096288}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Dictionary of Gods and Goddesses, Devils and Demons|author=Manfred Lurker|article=Tomam|pages=250|publisher=Routledge|date=1987|isbn=9780710208774}}</ref> {{asia-myth-stub}}
== References == <references />
== See also == * [[Khosedam]]

[[Image:Palazzo pubblico rsm.jpg|thumb|The [[Palazzo Pubblico (San Marino)|Palazzo Pubblico]] at daytime]] '''Tourism in San Marino''' contributes a large part of [[San Marino]]'s [[Gross domestic product|GDP]], with approximately 2 million [[Tourism|tourists]] visiting per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5387.htm|title=Background Note: San Marino|date=February 2010|publisher=U.S. State Department|accessdate=13 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401232347/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5387.htm|archivedate=1 April 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="rtv">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanmarinortv.sm/economia/default.asp?id=33&id_n=39203|title=Turismo: San Marino fa i conti con la recessione economica, l'Italia guarda con fiducia al 2010|date=11 January 2010|publisher=San Marino RTV|language=Italian|accessdate=13 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511135215/http://www.sanmarinortv.sm/economia/default.asp?id=33&id_n=39203|archivedate=11 May 2011|df=}}</ref>
Most tourists who visit San Marino are [[Italy|Italian]], usually consisting of people who come to spend holidays in the Romagna riviera and decide to spend a half-day or at most a night in the country.<ref name="rtv"/> Even though there are only a small number of non-Italian foreigners who visit the country, they still are vital to the Sammarinese economy.
There are no border formalities with Italy. However, at the tourist office visitors can purchase souvenir stamps which are officially canceled inside their [[passport]]s.
The [[City of San Marino]] itself contains most attractions. The City is perched on a hill with regular parking areas for cars and buses. The City historic center itself is only a pedestrian zone that has mostly gift shops and food venues on both sides.
== Visitor attractions == The main tourist attractions in the most popular destination in the country, the City of San Marino, and the rest of the nation are:
* [[The Three Towers of San Marino]] (The First Guita Tower, The Second Cesta Tower, and the Third Montale Tower) * The Cathedral of San Marino * The medieval [[Palazzo Pubblico (San Marino)|Palazzo Pubblico]] * The Piazza della Libertà, including the Statua della Libertà * The Museo di stato di San Marino, or the State Museum of San Marino * The Museo San Francesco * The small medieval alleyways, shop-lined streets, scenic terraces and little churches all dispersed around the city and the country.
=== Medieval Days festival === Once a year, the world's smallest Republic revives its history when it turns into a theatrical spectacle of the Medieval Days festival. Every July, San Marino entices people within its ancient walls to experience the microstate's centuries-old stories in its medieval village.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photographs of the Medieval Days festival in San Marino|url=https://independent-travellers.com/san_marino/|work=independent-travellers.com|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref>
